BY day, Larry Carroll works as a software engineer at the Boeing Company, putting animated figures through their paces in 3-D replicas of cockpits and workspaces. But Mr. Carroll's heart belongs on the dance floor. A longtime dancer, he saw his first tango class 11 years ago and, he says, fell in love. Four years ago, he wrote an online manual (home .att.net/larrydla/basics

Mr. Carroll, 58, grew up in Texas, where his uncle ran a honky-tonk: ''I learned swing, the two-step and the cowboy stuff at a very early age.'' After the Air Force and an early career in television production, his interest in software took him to NASA and then to Boeing. And, of course, he kept dancing.

''Most good engineers also have a strong creative bent,'' he says. ''Otherwise, they would just be plodders.'' He has just added a new page to his site for people who want to learn the steps in just one minute. He has called it, with an engineer's precision, ''0 to Tango in 60 Seconds.''
